steps.title: Mmk is a combination of â€œmmmâ€ and â€œokayâ€ that usually indicates disapproval.
steps.content: Mmk is a combination of â€œmmmâ€ and â€œokayâ€ that usually indicates disapproval. Itâ€™s a humming, drawn-out way to say â€œokay,â€ with the added "mmm" usually adding a note of disapproval or some other negative feeling. [1] X Research source In texting and on social media, you will most likely see mmk written in lowercase letters rather than all uppercase.

steps.title: Show disinterest.
steps.content: Show disinterest. Let the person youâ€™re texting know that you really donâ€™t care about whatever it is theyâ€™re talking about and that you donâ€™t have a lot of thoughts on the topic. â€œmmk sure if you want.â€ â€œmmk yeah sure, whatever you guys want, I donâ€™t really care.â€ â€œmmk yeah, I mean itâ€™s up to you. Iâ€™m free all weekend.â€

steps.title: Let them know that youâ€™re agreeing, but tentatively.
steps.content: Let them know that youâ€™re agreeing, but tentatively. Slightly less enthusiastic than saying â€œYes,â€ mmk lets the other person know that youâ€™re agreeing to whatever it is theyâ€™re saying, but youâ€™re still a bit hesitant. Let them know that youâ€™re okay with the idea, just not bursting with excitement. â€œmmk. I have some work left to do, so weâ€™ll see.â€ â€œmmk well, let me know when you get that figured out.â€ â€œmmk I mean, we havenâ€™t seen them in like a year, but if you want to invite them go ahead.â€

steps.title: Let someone know youâ€™re suspicious of what theyâ€™re saying.
steps.content: Let someone know youâ€™re suspicious of what theyâ€™re saying. Express your disbelief towards whatever was just said in a more passive-aggressive way. Youâ€™re not directly calling them out for being a liar or for exaggerating, but youâ€™re making it clear that things seem a bit sus. â€œmmk yeah that makes total sense.â€ â€œmmk sure.â€ â€œmmk yeah I definitely believe that.â€

steps.title: Let them know that youâ€™re annoyed.
steps.content: Let them know that youâ€™re annoyed. Mmk can be used to let the other person know that you feel annoyed by whatever they just said, or that you feel seriously inconvenienced if theyâ€™re asking for a favor from you. â€œmmk I guess.â€ â€œmmk got it.â€ â€œmmk yeah Iâ€™ll be sure to do that.â€

steps.title: Show some affection.
steps.content: Show some affection. This is kind of a one-eighty from the other examples, but mmk can actually express a warm and affectionate feeling if used in the right context. It sounds much softer than just a standard â€œokay.â€ â€œmmk yeah. Iâ€™d really like that.â€ â€œmmk yeah Iâ€™m actually really excited.â€ â€œmmk just tell me a time and place and Iâ€™ll be there.â€

steps.title: Repeat what you just said.
steps.content: Repeat what you just said. If someone doesnâ€™t seem interested in what youâ€™re saying, repeat it one more time so that they understand that this is something important or something you really want to talk about. You : We decided weâ€™re going out Friday. Is that okay with you? Them : mmk yeah sure whenever is fine. You : But will Friday actually work for you?

steps.title: Ask for a clear answer.
steps.content: Ask for a clear answer. When someone gives you a tentative â€œYesâ€ by sending mmk, ask a follow up question to get a more exact answer out of them if you really need to know. You : Wanna go to the zoo with me tomorrow? Them : mmk I mean, I have work to do, but I might be able to go. You : Okay well, when exactly are you free?

steps.title: Let them know you mean what you say.
steps.content: Let them know you mean what you say. If it sounds like someone doesnâ€™t believe what youâ€™re saying, emphasize that you are being completely serious and are telling the truth. Of course, if you happen to be lying, this may not work, but if you mean what you say, then donâ€™t be afraid to stick up for yourself. You : I almost beat him in our game yesterday! Them : mmk yeah I bet. You : Itâ€™s true! ğŸ˜­ I have a screenshot of the final score if you want proof.

steps.title: Call them out.
steps.content: Call them out. If someone is being overly sarcastic and condescending towards you and treating your words with a patronizing tone, donâ€™t be afraid to call them out on it. Make it clear that you donâ€™t appreciate such dismissive language being used towards you. [2] X Research source You : Make sure you text me when you get there. Them : mmk whatever. You : Iâ€™m just looking out for your safety.

steps.title: Donâ€™t engage.
steps.content: Donâ€™t engage. Sometimes itâ€™s best to just let someone be if theyâ€™re being difficult. They may be implying that they just donâ€™t feel like talking by sending you mmk, so leaving them alone for a while is totally okay. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms.
steps.content: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms. Learn these popular slang terms to stay in the know and keep your texts looking like English instead of gibberish: ISK : A typo for IDK (â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€) or â€œI should knowâ€ IDM : â€œI donâ€™t mindâ€ MCM : â€œMan crush Mondayâ€ WCW : â€œWoman crush Wednesdayâ€ MBN : â€œMust be niceâ€ FFF : â€œFollow for followâ€ PMO : â€œPut me onâ€ (introduce to someone or something) OOMF : â€œOne of my followersâ€ or â€œone of my friendsâ€ OMW â€™â€™: â€œOn my wayâ€
